Legal_Issue: Whether the Refugee Board erred in law by ignoring or disregarding evidence regarding the applicant's perceived clan membership
Application_Facts: The applicant, Ali, claimed refugee status based on a well-founded fear of persecution due to perceived Darod clan membership despite having Hawiye lineage; the Board focused on patrimonial lineage but ignored evidence about upbringing and family dynamics suggesting she was perceived as Darod
Decision_Outcome: The Federal Court quashed the Refugee Board’s decision
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Refugee Board's decision
Court_Ruling: The court found that the Board committed an error in law by failing to consider evidence of perceived social group membership; decision was overturned
Defendant_Behavior: Refugee Board dismissed the claim without adequately addressing evidence of perceived clan affiliation
Grounds_for_Claim: Perceived membership in a particular social group (Darod clan) leading to a well-founded fear of persecution
Legal_Standard: Convention refugee definition under Canadian law: well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Assessment_Factor: Perception of clan membership in Somalia, familial and social environment influencing identity perception
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), particularly provisions relating to Convention refugees
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application filed after Refugee Board dismissal
Review_Standard: Reasonableness, with questions of law subject to correctness standard
Evidence_Used: Evidence regarding the applicant's upbringing, family dynamics, and how she was perceived in her community
Legal_Provision_Cited: Definition of Convention refugee under Canadian immigration law
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to perceived membership in the Darod clan
Evidence_Assessed: Evidence of social perception of clan identity despite biological lineage
Governing_Rule: A Convention refugee must have a well-founded fear of persecution based on specified grounds, including membership in a particular social group
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to address evidence showing the applicant might be perceived as belonging to the Darod clan
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remitted to a new panel for redetermination
Harm_Assessment: Risk of persecution in country of origin due to misperceived clan affiliation
Cause_Description: Ali claimed refugee status fearing persecution because she was perceived as a member of the Darod clan due to her upbringing, even though her paternal lineage is Hawiye
Evidence_Handling: The Board improperly disregarded relevant evidence concerning perceived social group membership
Legal_Provision_Violated: Failure to properly apply the legal definition of a Convention refugee under Canadian law
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient consideration of non-biological factors in determining social group membership
Legal_Provision: Section 97 and Section 98 of IRPA – Definition and determination of Convention refugee status
Evidence_Assessment: The Federal Court found that the Board did not adequately assess evidence related to perceived identity
Decision_Rationale: Error in law occurred when the Board ignored evidence central to the applicant's claim of belonging to a particular social group by perception
Decision_Making_Body: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider all relevant evidence regarding perceived social group membership
Legal_Standard_Applied: Correctness for questions of law, reasonableness for factual findings
